content.description: This is located on the north-facing Epicurean Crag. A mostly 5.6 route with a perplexing awkward roof.  Going left through it felt like hard 5.10 going right felt more reasonable but a bit awkward maybe 5.9?  The rest of the route is mellow quartzite climbing.  This is one of the longer routes in the area.
content.location: Second route from the left on the north-facing Epicurean Crag.

content.description: An easy route for kids to check out. One bulge and a crack. Bring cams or run it out on the easy section to a 2-bolt station below the ledge. Tony Calderone & Elizabeth Griffin climbed this in 2017.
content.location: Located on the east face. This is the fourth route, from left to right, immediately left of an arete.

content.description: On the East face one of the two bolted routes.  Dirty, brushy, and "licheny" but should clean up with traffic.
content.location: On the East Face maybe 20 yards from the last picnic table.  Would be a nice area to take some kids if you're having a picnic and snag this site.

content.description: Short, straightforward, and the anchors at the top make it great for getting kids or really anyone used to relying on a rope and doing a mini-climb, or for practicing/teaching various safety skills.
content.protection: 2 anchors at the top, no chains or rings.
content.location: First little crag on the left if you enter at Ledgemere campground (which is just north of Dogwood) and take the path west.

content.description: Follow the bolts up and right of the sketchy flake. This flake looks precarious from below, but felt and appeared solid enough that some serious effort would be required to dislodge it. In any case, there are plenty of holds available to the right of this feature so avoiding any and all contact with the flake is probably wise. The bottom half of the climb is pretty unremarkable, but the upper face is good and leads to a cool top out. Small gear protects the final 15 feet or so to the chains.
content.protection: 4 bolts. Small to medium nuts or cams. Chain anchor.
content.location: Just to the right around the corner from the wall with 4 routes (Hopper, Lopper, Whipper, Whopper) you'll find this route with what looks like massive death flake protruding from the wall roughly 30 feet up.

content.description: Super slick water polished quartzite is the name of the game here.  This route starts off very easy with an easy roof (5.5). Protect with a 1.5” cam between bolts 3 and 4. These moves are delicate and thought-provoking with a left option or a right option to get to the next bolt.   From here it's up over the small roof and a couple more clips to the chains if memory serves.
content.location:
Fifth route from the left on the north-facing Epicurean Crag. Log seat with the route name at the staging area.

Starts near one of the only pine trees in the area on a north facing wall. Back is to a small clearing in the shrubs with an easy view of the road and stream.

content.description: Pull up and around a small roof. Scamper up low angle terrain to a 2-bolt station.
content.location: The left-most route on the north-facing Epicurean Crag.

content.description: Head up directly between the trees. Mellow climbing on decent rock.
content.location: This route climbs right up between a couple of trees. It is the 3rd bolted route from the right hand side.

content.description:
Fun, slabby, lots of room for creativity. Only continue to the top if you are very confident, a little crashpad won't save you here.

Careful for possibly loose chunks of rock.
content.location: First little crag on the left if you enter at Ledgemere campground (which is just north of Dogwood) and take the path west. This area is located at Ledgemere not Dogwood.

content.description: This is the left-most route on the east facing Site #13 Crag. Well-protected climbing up a highly featured face.
content.location: Left-most route on the wall at the very west end of the picnic area.

content.description: Slab up to a roof with a nice hole in the top. Sketch anchor set up from the hike around.

An excellent first traditional lead. Work your way up a slab for 20 or so feet until you reach the obvious crack that leads to the chain anchor above. Somewhat limited gear placement opportunities available before reaching the crack.
content.protection: Single rack to 2 inches. Chain anchor.
content.location: Sixth route from the left on the north-facing Epicurean Crag. Follow the trail west beyond the engraved logs  "Epicurean Crag Zipper"  and "Slipper". Watch for the obvious crack above that makes up the bulk of this route.

content.description: A moderate sport climb with the crux coming around bolt 2 or 3
content.location: Third route from the left on the north-facing Epicurean Crag.

content.description: Great warmup, short. Lots more V0-V2 options right there.
content.protection: Anchors at the top even though it's only 15'.
content.location: First little crag on the left if you enter at Ledgemere campground (which is just north of Dogwood) and take the path west.

content.description: Located on Picnic Site #10 Rock. Climb the right side of the east facing wall, up through a couple of mellow roofs.
content.location: This route and Bantam Slab are located towards the west end of the picnic area, before you reach the final wall with 4 bolted routes located roughly 20 feet west from the very last picnic table.

content.description: Located on the north side of Site #10 Rock. Clip 2 bolts on decent rock before placing some optional gear in more broken up rock before reaching the chains.
content.protection: 2 bolts plus small to medium cams, chain anchor
content.location: This climb faces north and is located on a wall shortly before reaching the last picnic table area where 4 bolted routes are located.

content.description: Looks like black bricks, easy and fun.
content.location: Second or third little crag on the left if you enter at Ledgemere campground (which is just north of Dogwood) and take the path west. Right by the camping spot with a cave.
